awd_titl_txt: RUI: The Circumgalactic Medium in the Local Universe
awd_abstract_narration:
Astronomers seek to understand how stars and galaxies formed.  Galaxies have come to exist in relation to the diffuse gas that surrounds them.  Understanding this relationship is essential for understanding how galaxies, including our own galaxy (the Milky Way), evolved into their present forms.  Ribaudo and colleagues will combine observations of nearby galaxies and their surrounding gas made with the Arecibo Observatory with other ground-based observations as well Hubble Space Telescope archival data. These combined observations probe the constituents of the gas surrounding galaxies and its physical distribution.  Such information reveals the inter-relationship between this gas and the galaxies within.  This project will provide educational research opportunities for three undergraduate students at Utica College and laboratory activities for undergraduate education.   This project will also include outreach to the Utica Children?s Museum, where the PI has previously been involved.  Such outreach activities may include creating ?dirty snowballs? to illustrate comet formation and hands-on spectroscopy and observing programs.

Ribaudo and collaborators will use results of the Arecibo Legacy Fast ALFA (ALFALFA) Survey to generate a sample of galaxies for study.  Their physical properties are determined in conjunction with data from the Sloan Digital Sky Survey (SDSS).  The CircumGalactic Medium (CGM) is investigated using absorption spectroscopy of background quasars from archival Hubble Space Telescope Cosmic Origins Spectrograph data.  They will characterize the CGM using absorption line diagnostics including Lyman-alpha, CII, SiII, SiIII, NV and OVI.  They will investigate covering fractions, equivalent widths of spectral lines and metallicities.  These researchers will characterize the properties of the CGM of galaxies in the nearby universe and compare them to previous studies at z > 0.1 and smaller studies of more nearby galaxies.   Results of this work will be presented by undergraduates at regional (New York area) and national (AAS) astronomy conferences in addition to being published in refereed journals.

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual Merit: 

We have explored the circumgalactic environments of HI-rich galaxies in the nearby universe by combining archival ground and space-based QSO absorption spectroscopy with the extragalactic source catalog from the ALFALFA survey. In doing so, we have identified several thousand QSO/Galaxy pairs from which we base our analysis of the CGM of HI-rich galaxies. Through our work we found the CGM environments of the ALFALFA galaxies is highly correlated with the HI-mass of the galaxy. The most HI-rich galaxies are associated with the most extended CGM, with the majority of sightlines passing within 300 kpc of these galaxies showing associated HI absorption. This is in contrast to the lowest HI-mass galaxies in ALFALFA, where the majority of sightlines passing beyond 50 kpc of these galaxies showing no discernible HI absorption. This suggests an interesting connection between the HI-mass in the ISM of a galaxy and the HI-mass in the CGM. In addition, we have found the CGM remains patchy, even at the smallest impact parameters, providing insight into the physical distribution of the CGM over a large range of galaxy mass environments.

We have created a project database containing detailed information on the data and objects used for the study. This includes properties and spectra for each QSO sightline along with galaxy properties derived from ALFALFA and SDSS and galaxy spectra (when publicly available). The database also includes the models/templates used in analyzing the QSO/galaxy data.

We have created Jupyter notebooks outlining the project analysis and demonstrating how to derive the results from the project.

 

Broader Impacts:

Over the lifetime of the award, 12 undergraduate students participated in research activities directly related to the project. Of the students who have graduated, three of these students are currently pursuing their PhD (one in Mathematics, one in Medical Physics, and one in Chemistry).

Dr. Ribaudo established an astrophysics research program at a local public high school, providing students with the opportunity to develop math, science, and computer programming literacy.
